entry.title: Variance Distilled
entry.content:
Scala Variance Distilled

Introduction

This article could have been called YAASV (‚ÄúYet Another Article on Scala Variance‚Äù).

There is already a lot of (good!) resources about variance out there (more about that in the next section). So why making another article about it?

Well, because if reading these resources gives actually a good grasp on the basics such as the definition, the technical aspect of it, the mental model (producer/consumer) that one has to build in order to understand it better, I always finished my reading without feeling that I could practically use this knowledge. It was still a bit abstract, the kind of academic one that is useful to understand type signature but was not really part of my realm, my toolbox.

The picture changed recently when I received some really pertinent explanation thanks to a workshop on Functional Data Modelling given by John de Goes. I got some answer about apparently very basic questions: Why is variance implanted in the Scala language? What does it bring to the table? Should it be use with parsimony or wherever possible? How does the (type inference) world look without it? ‚Ä¶and so on.

By the end, the picture seemed kind of clear so I decided that I should write something about it in order to prove to myself that I actually really understood it. But I wanted to cover some gaps I could see in other resources so that it eventually can be a practical thing for others.

Some other good resource that you would want to try‚Ä¶

If your patient enough to read whole chapters of books you may want to give a try to these excellent ones:

  • Martin Odersky, Lex Spoon, and Bill Venners, ‚ÄúProgramming in Scala, 4th Ed. (or 2nd or 3rd) Ed., Chap 19‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúDean Wampler, Programming Scala 3rd (or 2nd) Ed., Chap. 11‚Äù

If you just want to read a few introductions on it you certainly would enjoys these also:

  • Scala Generics II
  • Covariance & Contravariance in Scala
  • Contravariance in the Real World
  • Scala Variance explained

‚Ä¶or read what follows of course.

Organisation

I think that a practical understanding of variance have to include an answer to the following questions:

  • What is it? Meaning: What is the definition and can we dissect every hard concept of it so that every part is clear?
  • How is it implemented in Scala? Meaning: how does it appear in Scala code or how to use it?
  • Why is there variance? Meaning: what does it brings to the table for us? (and how much does we have to pay for it in terms of constraint?)

What is variance?

Variance is given to parameter(s) of type constructors. It is an assertion made to the Scala compiler that, given an existing subtyping relationship between concrete types, we want it to enforce a subtyping relationship between type constructors that were built with these types.

Yeah, I know. A mouthful. But, actually, every bits of this definition is important. So let‚Äôs break it.

First of all we need a subtyping relationship between concrete types. What is it? This:

A concrete type hierarchy:

// I have this hierarchy of types
//             A
//            ‚Üó ‚Üñ
//           B   C

trait A
trait B extends A 
trait C extends A 

// what is (one of) the power behind it? This!
// A is an A, B is an A and, C is an A
val a1: A = new A{}
val a2: A = new B{}
val a3: A = new C{}

During the article I will refer to this hierarchy again and again without always display it again

On the other side we have type constructors.

They are also types but not concrete ones (they are called higher kinded types).

As their name (type constructors) suggest, a concrete type can be built from them. In practice, you feed a type constructor one (or more..) concrete types and you receive a concrete type.

// this is a type constructor
// by the way T is called a "type parameter" and you can have many of them.
// Container[T] can also be called a "parametric type" because...it has a type parameter :)
// Because parametriciy is also called genericity in Java, they are also call generic types.
trait Container[T] 

// or other more commons
// I omitter the variance because I still haven't introduced it!
trait Option[T]
trait Either[A,B]
trait Future[T]
trait ZIO[R,E,A]

// building a concrete type out of it
type ContainerOfInt = Container[Int]
// buiding a value....
val c1: ContainerOfInt = new Container[Int]{}

If you want a nice and deep intuition you can put it like that: type constructors are equivalent to functions operating at type level. If a function is ‚Äúgive me one (or more) value I will return you another one‚Äù (value level), the type constructor is ‚Äúgive me one (or more) types I will return you a concrete one‚Äù (type level).

Now, what is crucial to understand is that we get to fix the variance of a type constructor. We decide in a complete arbitrary fashion what will be the subtyping relationship of a given type constructor (Container[T]) that wraps a concrete hierarchy of types.

Again: YOU have to decide. Of course, it is usually backed by serious design arguments (more later about it), but it stays that it is an arbitrary decision i.e an ‚Äúassertion you make to the compiler‚Äù.

Of course, once the type is set on a specific variance, the compiler will enforce some rules that will constraint our type contructors (its methods‚Ä¶) but also gives us more power in certain case.

But how do we actually enforce variance‚Ä¶

How do we enforce variance?

There are three type of variance that can be enforce in Scala, provided this hierarchy:

Reminder of the above concrete type hierary:

// I have this hierarchy of types
//             A
//            ‚Üó ‚Üñ
//           B   C
Variance Declaration Type constructor subtyping relationship
Covariance Container[+T] 
// I have this resulting hierarchy of type constructor
//             Container[A]  Container[A]         
//                 ü†ë             ü†ë    
//             Container[B]  Container[C]
Invariance Container[T] 
// Container[A], Container[B] and Container[C]
// are completely unrelated types from the compiler 
// point of view.
Contravariance Container[-T] 
// I have this resulting hierarchy of type constructor
//             Container[B]  Container[C]         
//                 ü†ë             ü†ë    
//             Container[A]  Container[A]

Some important remarks:

  • Variance can be applied only on immutable types.
  • Variance is set only at declaration of type constructors in Scala (it is called declaration site variance).
  • A single container may have multiple parameter types having different variance e.g ZIO[-R, +E, +A] We say that ZIO is contravariant in R and covariant in E and A‚Ä¶and invariant in Nothing :)

All this is really nice, but what the heck is it good for? Is there some implications on compilation, some contraints on types? How are designed types with respect to variance?

But why variance after all?

We said it, enforcing variance is arbitrary. In other word, you get to decide the [+, (nothing here), -] that is going to adorn you type constructor‚Äôs type parameters.

Once you commit to a specific variance for a specific type parameter you make a trade with the Scala compiler:

  • You pay: ‚Äúsevere‚Äù restriction on the way you code your method on the Container[T] (more on this later).
  • You have: the is a relationship of your container wrapping types is real and this allows to code methods for a variety of types one time because it will be availale to all the subtype.
  • You have: crazy good type inference!

Let‚Äôs explain the second point.

By applying variance, you get a parameter passing experience that relates ‚Äúcorrecly‚Äù to the intuitiion, the feeling that it should work!

For instance, given our above A/B/C hierarchy and List[+A] being covariant it is natural to think that if a method take a List[A], it should also accept a List[B] or a List[C]

Why? This is interesting actually. In our mind, we know that the way to use a List is actually to get some elements out of it (i.e List produces elements for us) so we guess that any subtype of the list type should work because a subtype just increase the power (i.e have more methods, more fields for instance) of its supertype and therefore can be used in place of the supertype (this is called the Liskov Substitution Principle).

But hey, this is cool! I know that wherever I need an A I can actually provide a B or a C and the above section showed me that a List[A] could be replaced by a List[B] or a List[C]! So it goes in the same direction no? Could we consider a List[B] a subtype of List[A]? Totally! This is called covariance!

With our Container[_] type:

// suppose Container has been declared invariant
trait Container[T]

// A, B and C are concrete type according to the above hierarchy
val c1: Container[A] = ???
val c2: Container[B] = ???
val c3: Container[C] = ??? 

// a method taking a Container of the concrete type A
def foo(l: Container[A]): A = ???

// if Container is invariant in A like the declaration above 
foo(c1) // this compile
foo(c2) // this DOES NOT compile
foo(c3) // this DOES NOT compile

// now suppose Container has been declared covariant
trait Container[+T]
foo(c1) // this compile
foo(c2) // this compile
foo(c3) // this compile

Some important take away:

  • We can code for multiple type in a secure (compiler controller) fashion with variance.
  • better type inference is not a caprice but actually a pretty handy feature!

What do we owe to the Scala compiler?

Now, we have understood the ‚ÄúWhat‚Äù and the ‚ÄúHow‚Äù of variance and even a good bit of the ‚ÄúWhy‚Äù (we got an intuition about why a type could be logically covariant).

Still two important questions are pending:

  • When a type constructor is designed (such as Array[T], Option[+A], Function1[-T1, +R], List[+A], ZIO[-R,+E,+A]‚Ä¶), i.e how does the variance is decided for its type parameters?
  • While coding the method of the container we may trigger ‚Äústrange‚Äù errors from the compiler telling us that a given type parameters occurs in ‚Äúcovariant‚Äù or ‚Äúcontravariant‚Äù position.

What does it mean? What can we do about it?

The Producer/Consumer mental model

This part will attempt to explain the first of the above points.

Suppose we think about a data type i.e a new Container[T] (immutable with a single type parameter) that is going to have some interesting properties.

Now, we are asking ourselves: Is Container invariant, covariant or contravariant in T?

To answer this question we have to imagine our data type in action. So let‚Äôs suppose we have a function that take it as a parameter and will do something interesting with it:

def doStuffWithContainer[T](c: Container[T]): Unit 
// or it could be
def doStuffWithContainer[T](c: Container[T]): T 
// or also
def doStuffWithContainer[T](t: T, c: Container[T]): Unit

Note: this is not really a function but a parametric function (‚Äúa function constructor‚Äù) whose type has to be fixed at compile time but we want to make it simple here so we‚Äôll call it a function!

The implementation of doStuffWithContainer is going to interact with the container in ways that we could sum-up:

  • Receiving some T from it
  • Passing some T to it
  • Do both

Other possibilities:

  • Do nothing with it but, but that is not very intersting nor it is well designed‚Ä¶
  • Do something with the container that does not involve any T. This is actually interesting as it paves the way to some explanation about path dependent type but let put it aside because it is not the subject.

Let‚Äôs see what happen with the above hypothese.

Receiving some T from the Container

This means that once we fix the type T (let‚Äôs say for the concrete type A doStuffWithContainer[A]) any instance of a subtype of A could also be received without problem by the implementation of the function. This means in particular that: B and C would also work. In other words if:

// I have this hierarchy of types
//             A
//            ‚Üó ‚Üñ
//           B   C

and‚Ä¶

doStuffWithContainer[A](new Container[A]{}) // work
doStuffWithContainer[A](new Container[B]{}) // would work also ideally!
doStuffWithContainer[A](new Container[C]{}) // would work also ideally!

If Container[T] is invariant in T, Container[A], Container[B] and Container[C] will be completely unrelated types from the compiler point of view (so the last 2 line of the above code will not work!).

But if Container[+T] is covariant in T it will work without problem.

To sum-up:

If our function implementation is receiving some values of type T out of the container, covariance seems the way to go in order to accept not just Container[T] but Container of all it subtype also! In other word, when we need the type to be a Producer of values we make it Contravariant.

Passing some T to the Container

This means that if we fix the type of the method to the concrete type, say B, it will internally pass some B to the Container. If the Container is asking for Bs or any supertype of B, the function will perform correctly. In particular: B, A, Any would work. So, if:

// I have this hierarchy of types
//            Any 
//             ü†ï
//             A
//            ‚Üó ‚Üñ
//           B   C

and‚Ä¶

val b: B = ???
doStuffWithContainer[B](b, new Container[B]{}) // work
doStuffWithContainer[B](b, new Container[A]{}) // would work also ideally!
doStuffWithContainer[B](b, new Container[Any]{}) // would work also ideally!

If Container[T] is invariant in T, Container[A], Container[B] and Container[Any] will be completely unrelated types from the compiler point of view (so the last 2 line of the above code will not work!).

But if Container[-T] is contravariant in T it will work without problem.

To sum-up:

If our function implementation is passing some values of type T to the container, contravariance seems the way to go in order to accept not just Container[T] but Container of its supertypes also! In other word, when we need the type to be a Producer of values we make it Contravariant.

Compilation problems relative to covariant/contravariant position

Problem with Covariant container

Suppose the following code:

trait A
trait B extends A { def foo(): Int = 0 }
trait C extends A { def bar(): Int = 1 }

sealed trait CovContainer[+T] {
  def insider: T
  def doStuff(t: T): T // this cannot compile!
}

object CovContainer {
  def make(i: Int): CovContainer[Int] =
    new CovContainer[Int] {
      def insider: Int = i
      def doStuff(t: Int): Int = t + i
    }
}

Here we are trying to create a Producer type so we make it covariant according to what we discovered.

The doStuff(t: T): T function does not compile and we receive this message from the compiler:

[E]  covariant type T occurs in contravariant position in type T of value t
[E]  L21:     def doStuff(t: T): T
[E]                       ^^^^

The compiler is trying to tell us that our code is not sound for the moment i.e it could lead to some contradictions. If we accept that our code are actually logical assertion, the compiler says that, had it compile the method reveiving t:T in parameter, we could create un-sound assertion. And indeed we could:

val cci: CovContainer[Int] = CovContainer.make(555)
println(cci.insider) // would have return 555
println(cci.doStuff(111)) // would have return 666

// let see what kind of contradiction we can tell the compiler to create
// this work because the Container is declared contravariant
val cca: CovContainer[Any] = cci
// BOOOOM!!!! This will try to add Int to String
println(cca.doStuff("Hi, I am sam"))

We can fix the method this way:

def doStuff[T1 >: T](t: T1): T1

This mean that if we are willing to pass a paramter (i.e be a Consumer type) then the implementation need to be valid for any type T1 that can be Int but also any other concrete supertype of it. This drastically reduce the possible implementations but at the same time it reveal the high price (with respect to soundness) of being both covariant with a contravariant method.

Problems with Contravariant container

In the same fashion on this code as a base:

  trait A
  trait B extends A { def foo(): Int = 0 }
  trait D extends B { def bar(): Int = 1 }

  trait ContraContainer[-T] {
    def passMe(t: T): Unit
    def doStuff(t: T): T
  }

  object ContraContainer {
    def make(b: B): ContraContainer[B] =
      new ContraContainer[B] {
        private var bb: B = b
        def passMe(t: B): Unit = println(t)
        def doStuff(b: B): B = bb
      }
  }

We have this type of error on def doStuff(t: T): T:

[E] contravariant type T occurs in covariant position in type (t: T)T of method doStuff
[E] L54:     def doStuff(t: T): T
[E]                       ^^^^

And would it compile, we could create an unsound code that lead to a contradiction:

  val cvc1 = ContraContainer.make(new B {})
  cvc1.passMe(new B {})
  cvc1.doStuff(new B {})

  // this is possible because ContraContainer is contravariant
  val cvc2: ContraContainer[D] = cvc1
  // booooom! This call bar() on the runtime B type that does not have it
  cvc2.doStuff(new D {}).bar()

The method doStuff has to be corrected as follows:

def doStuff[T1 <: T](t: T1): T1

The example of ZIO

The ZIO library provide numerous good example of the way to deal with variance (both co- and contra-).

The ZIO type as the following simplified signature:

sealed trait ZIO[-R, +E, +A]

It is contravariant in R (the environment) and covariant in E the error type and A the success type.

In the light of what has been studied here, it can be understood as:

  • A consumer type of an environment (R)
  • A producer type of either an error E either a succcess value A

Let‚Äôs take a method so see how the contravariant/covariant position error are avoided:

/**
 * Returns an effect that executes both this effect and the specified effect, in parallel, returning result of provided effect.
 */
&>[R1 <: R, E1 >: E, B](that: ZIO[R1, E1, B]): ZIO[R1, E1, B]

Reading this [R1 <: R, E1 >: E, B] we can now understand that:

  • producing a ZIO value with a contravariant type, we need R1 <: R to satisfy the compiler.
  • consuming a ZIO value with an covariant type, we need E1 >: E to satify the compiler.
  • the purpose of the method being to return the that effect we just need to return B here.

Conclusion

  • Variance is a subtyping relationship between type constructors given a subtyping relationship between concrete types
  • The subtyping relationship can follow the underlying types relationship (covariance), invert it (contravariance) or forget the underlying relationship (invariance).
  • Applying variance to a type parameter when declaring a type constructor is the responsibility of the creator of the type.
  • The variance can be decided according to the role (Producer/Consumer/Both) of the type parameter in the type constructor
  • Variance brings several advantage such as better type inference but also increase the range of type contructors that can be substituted securely without relying on explicit upcast
  • Eventually, there is ways to deal with compiler constraint on ‚Äúcontravariant position‚Äù error when the type is covariant or ‚Äúcovariant position‚Äù error when the type is contravariant.

entry.title: Bash Notes - Part 2
entry.content:
Bash Notes (Part 2) - Transforming the input

Introduction

In the first part, I introduced the reader to the basic of writing scripts (shebang, comments, parameters, variable and quoting‚Ä¶).

This second part focuses on processing input parameter or variables of a script: checking parameters, providing default, extracting part via pattern/regexp and calculating.

The main keywords are: variable expansion, parameter expansion, pattern matching, regular expression and arithmetic evaluation. Searching man bash (Internet‚Ä¶) for this will give wider details and explanations.

Parameter expansion

substitution operator meaning
${VAR:-value} Does not set the variable. Return $VAR if set else return value
${VAR:=value} Set the variable with value if not set and return $VAR.
${VAR:?message} If $VAR is set show its value else display message
${VAR:offset:length} If $VAR is set show the $VAR from offset to offset + length

The last line shows a primitive way of taking a part of the variable without touching it. A typical example of this is taking a part of a date for instance.

Pattern matching & Regular expressions

A better way to take some part of a variable (sentence, text, number‚Ä¶) is to use pattern matching.

Here are the most commonly used parameter expansion using patterns.

substitution operator meaning
${VAR#pattern} Trim $VAR from the beginning to the first occurence of the pattern (including it) else return the $VAR untouched
${VAR##pattern} Trim $VAR from the beginning to the last occurence of the pattern (including it) else return the $VAR untouched
${VAR%pattern} Trim $VAR from the end to the first occurence of the pattern (including it) else return the $VAR untouched
${VAR%%pattern} Trim $VAR from the end to the last occurence of the pattern (including it) else return the $VAR untouched
${#VAR} Variable length

Patterns are written in a small language allowing to specify sets of strings. It can be used with a lot of bash builtins commands (see: man bash-builtins).

pattern extglob meaning
* no Match zero or more characters
? no Match any single character
[‚Ä¶] no Match any of the characters in a set
[:class:] no Class of char (POSIX standard): alnum alpha ascii blank cntrl digit graph lower print punct space upper word xdigit
?(patterns) yes Match zero or one occurrences of the patterns (extglob)
*(patterns) yes Match zero or more occurrences of the patterns (extglob)
+(patterns) yes Match one or more occurrences of the patterns (extglob)
@(patterns) yes Match one occurrence of the patterns (extglob)
!(patterns) yes Match anything that doesn‚Äôt match one of the patterns (extglob)
| yes logical OR between pattern

(this is inspired by the short but very explainful)

extglob: Use extending globbing (the pattern language) capabilities. Activation can be checked by shopt extglob. shopt give you the state of your shell options.

Beside this, some non internal commands are very often in use when writing scripts. And at their heart stands the use of Regular Expressions(RegExp) which is a much more extended language to search for pattern in a text.

For instance:

  • grep (stands for g/re/p or globally regular expression parsing/printing) is the source to understand your system regular expression standards (thers is many according to the tool. Documentation.
  • sed Stream Editor that make extensive use of RegExp. Documentation.
  • awk Aho - Weinberg - Kernighan a more involved programming language used for parsing. Documentation.

Although a big subset of this language is common to all of them, there is now many standards of Regular Expression in use depending on the tool/programming language (see: reference on standards). So beware to check on the one in used with your tool.

Calculating

These are the practical means to compute from variables:

  • Arithmetic Evaluation (search it in man bash) is internal. Arithmetic expression can be evaluated with:

    $((<arithmetic expression>))

  • bc Basic Calculator is an external command that extend the calculation capabilities (float‚Ä¶). bc can be used for instance:

    echo "<bc programm>" | bc

    or if directly fill a variable with:

    VAR=$(echo "<bc programm>" | bc)

Exercise

This script illustrate the use of the knowledge above.

#!/bin/bash
# This script date a format date X-Y-Z and split it.
# It writes also:
# The day X, The month Y, The year Z

# Usage: ./splitdate 

TODAY=$(date +%d-%m-%y)

DIG=[[:digit:]]
DIG2=$DIG$DIG
DAYMONTH=${TODAY%%-$DIG2}

echo "The day is ${TODAY%%-$DIG2-$DIG2}"
echo "The month is ${DAYMONTH#$DIG2-}"
echo "The year is ${TODAY##$DIG2-$DIG2-}"

# Bonus :-)
# echo "Next year will be $(( ${TODAY##$DIG2-$DIG2-} + 1 ))"

entry.title: Bash Notes - Part 1
entry.content:
Introduction

Not so long ago, I decided I needed to learn Bash more seriously. I already coded a bit in Bash, but all my knowledge was made of examples inferrence from various code encountered in blogs and StackOverflow etc.

Why learning bash (as a software developer) and not Python for instance? Well, various reasons:

  • There is a huge existing codebase of bash script in the Unix/MacOS/Linux world‚Ä¶and I may have to understand what it does sometimes.
  • Bash is a lingua franca meaning that you may have Bash at your disposal without having Python
  • It is really powerful and OS connected

While copying code is a perfect way to learn when you want practical (fast) results, you end-up gropping around a bit too much when you want to make something new without mentioning not having a single idea of certain feature being available that could save your life :)

This post is NOT:

  • A tutorial (but could be maybe used as one)
  • A complete reference of the Bash scripting language. This is one
  • A quick unexplicative post about a single feature of the language‚Ä¶there is more than enough

These are simply my (enriched) notes of the excellente course of Sander Van Vugt that I want to keep organised and maybe useful to others.

Like every course notes, one makes the maximum of it when it already have some knowledge (even scattered) and have to organise them, review a technical point, grab some useful tips and know-how. The advantage here is it is very practical (by opposition to filled with theoretical details) so it allows both to write script fast and also to read them (on your own OS).

Another purpose is to give the actual correct terminology of the part of this language as much as some sub-languages because they are the key for searching for more explanation on the Internet or any other source of documentation. For instance, you may encounter something like ${VAR:-somethingElse} and know that some code is being interpreted inside the curly braces. It will be even faster if you already know that this is called parameter expansion and that there is plenty of other way to apply this technique (search for this term in the man of bash for instance).

Eventually, this is the first post (Part I) but there will be more as I continue to learn.

Hope it will serve you well! :)

Getting Help (out of $ man bash)

When you name a script beware that:

  • You have to put it on your $PATH
  • When name conflicts occurs (because the name of the script is an executable already existing in your system), this precedence is applied:
    • internal command
    • external command
    • your scipt

Internal commands which existence can be tested with:

$ type <name-of-command>

External commands which existence can be tested with:

$ which <name-of-command>

Get the list of the list of internal commands and optionally get some help about a specific command.

$ help [command name]

The authoritative doc is:

  • here
  • man bash (if you know what you want to search)
  • also man bash-builtins is really great as it gives you the internal commands of bash and the meaning/usage.

Variable and parameters

  • Don‚Äôt forget the shebang: #!/bin/bash. It gives the bash the language of the script in order to find the correct interpreter.
  • Put some comment explaining the purpose of the script
  • Put some usage information
  • Put exit 0 at the end of the script.

The last executed command exit status can be access with the variable: $?.

Variables

You can define them:

  • statically: MY_VAR=foo or export MY_VAR=foo (if you want any sub-shell to access it),
  • or as arguments of the script $0, $1, $2‚Ä¶
  • or interactively with read.

Variable are accessed with $. For instance: $MY_VAR

Script execution (shell/sub-shell)

  • A script (when lauched for instance by: ./my-script) is going to be executed in a sub-shell. Before the execution 2 script are going to be executed: /etc/bash.bashrc and ~/.bashrc.
  • If it is a login-shell 2 other file are executed first: /etc/profile and ~/.profile.
  • Good explanation about shell and sub-shell: here

Sourcing other scripts

Inside your script put:

. /path/of/the/sourced/script

alternatively

source /path/of/the/sourced/script

The main idea for a system script (even a small one), is to have static code in the sourced file and the dynamic code in the called script.

!!! Danger !!! don‚Äôt put exit codes in a sourced script (if you source it in your current shell then the exit would close your working shell)

Quoting

Reserved character (that need quoting):

Character Meaning Character Meaning
~ home dir ] end char set wildcard
` command substitution { start code block
# comment } end code block
$ variable expansion ; command separator
& background job ‚Äô strong quote
* wildcard string ‚Äù weak quote
( start sub-shell < input redirection
) end sub-shell > output redirection
\ escape / path separator
| pipe ? single char wildcard
[ start char set wildcard ¬† ¬†
  • ‚Äúhard‚Äù quote are ' and nothing is interpreted in it
  • ‚Äúweak‚Äù quote are " and variable, command substitution and _ arithmetic expression are interpreted in it

Handling script arguments

Variable Meaning Variable Meaning
$0 absolute path of the script $* string of all arguments
$1 first argument ($1‚Ä¶9 possible) $# number of arguments
$9 last argument accessible with $n $@ array of all arguments
more arg use ${} (not compatible with all shells) or shift ¬† ¬†
  • most of the time for number of arg (n > 9) use ${n}
  • shift is the only really compatible command no matter the shell.

Command substitution

Command substitution allows the output of a command to replace the command itself.

  • deprecated: `<my-command`
  • recommended: $(<my-command>)

Test string

  • test -z $1 && exit 1 (is checking for $1 to be empty and exit if it is the case
  • [[ $1=='[a-z]*' ]] || echo $1 does not start with a letter (check if the variable $1 respect the given pattern and echo a message if not)

Note: !!Warning!! put no space afer the variable name [[ $1 == pattern ]] is wrong because the shell would search for a variable called $1 instead of $1

Tips

Empty a file completly without erasing it

$ cat /dev/nul > the-file-to-be-emptied

Debug a script to see where it F#*$@&!-up

$ bash -x <my-script>

Read an array of variable

read -a <my-array-var>

Best practice

  • Use upper case just for variable names inside scripts
  • Separate static from dynamic code in scripts so that the static part can be portable.
  • Always use ' until you need "

Exercise

This script illustrate the use of the knowledge above.


#!/bin/bash
# This script take an undefine number of arguments.
# If the argument is a file it will copy it to /tmp
# if not argument is provided it read one from the command line
#
# Usage: ./totmp [arg1 [ arg2 [...]]]


if [[ $# == 0 ]]; then
# also possible: if [ -z $1 ]; then
	read FILE_NAME_LIST
else
	FILE_NAME_LIST=$@
fi

for i in $FILE_NAME_LIST;
do
	if [[ -f $i ]]; then
		cp $i /tmp
		echo file $i copied to /tmp
	fi
done
